title: How to write an answer on Quora - Quora

response.answer_text: On Quora, you can write an answer to a question from your feed or a question page by clicking the “Answer” button. You can write answers from the Write Answer page, when you see questions in your feed, and from topic pages. For more information about how to write helpful answers on Quora, check out this answer.

Before I begin writing an answer I go through a whole process to decide if I have something unique to say on the subject. If I’m going to just repeat what everyone else is saying then I’ll upvote the answers I enjoy and go on to another question. I go through that process here: Dirk Hooper's answer to What is your process of selecting good questions to answer? If I feel like there’s something I can add, then I literally just start writing. This is a new thing and it’s come after several years of being here on Quora. How often have you heard that writing becomes easier the more you do it? Guess what? It does. I’m not new to writing. I’ve been seriously interested in writing since I was very young and I took creative writing courses when I was around 13 years old. I took film and video studies in college, which is just basically learning how to write about film. And I’ve been published as a comic writer, a poet, and in numerous articles. But writing didn’t really become easy for me until I started writing for Quora. I have some foundational training in composition and I use those skills when I write. If you read my answers, most of them follow basic structure for a composition. Sticking to that makes my answers easy to read and it makes it easier to write. Basic Composition I will often frame the question in my own way, so if the question disappears or changes, my piece will still make sense. It also makes the piece better for publication elsewhere, if I get lucky enough to get recognized for a good answer. Then I do my best to set the plate and offer any background that’s needed to understand what’s led to my answer. I follow that up with a few points, or the meat of the answer. Finally, I wrap up the whole answer by summarizing what I’ve written and try to give a broader thought on the issue. Research While I’m writing an answer I’ll try to recall anything I’ve read that might back up what I’m saying. If I can’t come up with anything I might do a Google search to find some supporting material. In some cases, a solid quote from an authority on the subject can be a gift from glob, and bring authority to my own answer. I do my best to add links to sources as I go, it makes it much easier to add them while I write rather than go back and add them later. Editing Once I’m through with the answer I read it out loud. What I’ve discovered is that you’ll find a ton of mistakes that way. Since I don’t have a staff of editors who are looking out for what I’m writing, a brief look at my writing and syntax is the least I can do to try to not look like an idiot. (I removed several words from that last sentence when I read it back… it works.) I often remove something at the beginning or end that just goes on too much. What Quora Has Done for Me All of this is the same way that I’ve written since I was young. What’s different now is my experience in writing on Quora. What I used to do was create an outline, then do some brainstorming on the subject, do my research, get a lot of information in front of me, and then write the piece. After writing for several years on Quora all of this comes naturally. The hardest part of writing, for me, and maybe for you, is just getting started. I used to talk myself out of an article before I ever began. That doesn’t happen any more. I’m confident now that whatever I set out to write will come out fine. In fact, it’s probably confidence that Quora has given me the most. Writing regularly, seeing what others write, learning from them, and getting the feedback through upvotes and comments has forged my writing in fire. So Now? Now I simply start the answer and trust myself to get to the end. It’s made me far more productive. I’m still sticking to what I’ve learned about basic composition to get me through the process, and I edit it to make sure it’s easy to read, but it’s the power and confidence that I’ve gained by writing more often that has really set me free.
